# La grazia (2025 film) **La grazia** (English: "The Grace" or "The Pardon") is an Italian drama film written and directed by [Paolo Sorrentino](/article/en/Paolo_Sorrentino). It stars [Toni Servillo](/article/en/Toni_Servillo) as the protagonist, alongside [Anna Ferzetti](/article/en/Anna_Ferzetti) and [Massimo Venturiello](/article/en/Massimo_Venturiello). The film premiered as the opening film of the [82nd Venice International Film Festival](/article/en/82nd_Venice_International_Film_Festival) on 27 August 2025, where it competed for the [Golden Lion](/article/en/Golden_Lion). Servillo won the [Volpi Cup for Best Actor](/article/en/Volpi_Cup). It received theatrical release in [Italy](/article/en/Italy) on 15 January 2026. ## Plot President of the [Italian Republic](/article/en/Italian_Republic) Mariano De Santis is nearing the end of his term, having safely guided the country through six state crises. A widower, former legal expert, and devout [Catholic](/article/en/Catholic_Church), he is nicknamed "Reinforced Concrete" for his inflexibility and immovable character. De Santis is constantly accompanied by his daughter Dorotea, also a jurist who has drafted a law legalizing [euthanasia](/article/en/Euthanasia), and Colonel Massimo Labaro, a carabinieri officer. His only concession to private life includes dinners with his longtime friend Coco Valori, an effusive art critic. De Santis lives in perpetual memory of his deceased wife Aurora, haunted by awareness of her infidelity forty years earlier; he has never learned the identity of her lover. During his white semester (the final six months of a presidential term), De Santis faces three major moral dilemmas: whether to sign the euthanasia law into effect, and whether to grant pardons to two individuals convicted of murder under potentially mitigating circumstances. The first pardon petition concerns Professor Cristiano Arpa, who murdered his wife suffering from [Alzheimer's disease](/article/en/Alzheimer_disease) and subsequently allowed himself to die by refusing food. His former students, who regard him as wise and temperate, filed the pardon request. The second involves Isa Rocca, a woman imprisoned for stabbing her husband after fifteen years of domestic violence. Justice Minister Ugo Romani, De Santis's childhood friend and likely successor, suggests that De Santis carefully examine Rocca's case, revealing she is the niece of his companion. De Santis suspects Ugo may be Aurora's mysterious lover, though Coco denies this. Dorotea personally investigates Rocca's case, discovering the woman harbors no remorse and believes her act constituted a form of euthanasia, as her husband was incurable. Dorotea learns that Rocca has a lover waiting for her outside prison. De Santis's deliberations are further complicated by discussions with the [Pope](/article/en/Pope), his personal friend, regarding the euthanasia law. When his beloved horse Elvis becomes incurably ill, De Santis requests it not be euthanized while he postpones his decisions—a point of contention with Colonel Labaro. The horse eventually dies, possibly euthanized by Labaro. As his term concludes, Dorotea unexpectedly announces her departure to [Canada](/article/en/Canada) to join her brother, a contemporary music composer. Left alone, De Santis decides to personally address the outstanding matters. Shortly before his term ends, he reveals to Labaro his intention to resign two weeks early to become a Life Senator and participate in the presidential election. De Santis attends a premiere at the [Scala Theater](/article/en/La_Scala) in [Milan](/article/en/Milan), where he receives an ovation from the public. Coco observes that despite his constant doubts, the Italian people love him; De Santis replies that they love the idea of legality rather than the person who transmitted it. Coco then reveals an unexpected truth: she was Aurora's lover, freeing Mariano from decades of uncertainty, though De Santis retains doubt about whether Coco spoke truthfully or out of pity. After resigning from office, De Santis grants an interview to Vogue Italia, during which he reflects on his life and mistakes. He reveals that he signed the euthanasia law before leaving office, having matured the conviction that true "grace" is not achieving absolute certainty but having courage to make decisions despite doubt. He granted the pardon to Isa Rocca, believing her sincere, but denied it to Cristiano Arpa, whom he believes did not truly love his wife. De Santis retains uncertainty about whether Coco was truthful regarding Aurora. Text cards conclude the film: Rocca and her new partner separated six months after the pardon; Arpa filed an independent pardon request after repeatedly refusing the one his former students proposed; Justice Minister Ugo Romani failed in his run for the Quirinal by a single vote, likely De Santis's. ## Cast * Toni Servillo as Mariano De Santis, President of the Italian Republic * Anna Ferzetti as Dorotea De Santis, his daughter and jurist * Massimo Venturiello as Ugo Romani, Justice Minister * Orlando Cinque as Colonel Massimo Labaro, carabinieri officer * Milvia Marigliano as Coco Valori, art critic * Giuseppe Gaiani as Lanfranco Mare * Giovanna Guida as Valeria Cafiero * Alessia Giuliani as Maria Gallo * Roberto Zibetti as Domenico Samaritano * Linda Messerklinger as Isa Rocca * Vasco Mirandola as Cristiano Arpa, professor * Rufin Doh Zeyenouin as the Pope * Francesco Martino as Riccardo De Santis * Alexandra Gottschlich as the Lithuanian Ambassador * Guè (Italian rapper) as himself ## Production ### Development The film was announced on 4 December 2024, with Sorrentino as writer and director. Sorrentino revealed that the film's inspiration derived from the real case of a man pardoned by Italian [President](/article/en/President_of_Italy) [Sergio Mattarella](/article/en/Sergio_Mattarella) after being convicted of murdering his wife, who suffered from Alzheimer's disease. This marks Sorrentino's eleventh feature film as director. For Sorrentino and Servillo, it represents their seventh collaboration on a feature film. According to Sorrentino, he had wanted to create a "romantic film" with his favorite actor for twenty years, achieving this with *La grazia* while maintaining stylistic continuity rather than abruptly shifting from [Fellini](/article/en/Federico_Fellini) to [Truffaut](/article/en/François_Truffaut). The director and actor had "finally found the right tone to bring love to the screen." Previously, under Sorrentino's direction, Servillo had portrayed Italian [Prime Ministers](/article/en/Prime_Minister_of_Italy) [Giulio Andreotti](/article/en/Giulio_Andreotti) in *[Il Divo](/article/en/Il_Divo)* (2008) and [Silvio Berlusconi](/article/en/Silvio_Berlusconi) in *[Loro – The Seduced](/article/en/Loro_(2018_film))* (2018). ### Casting Toni Servillo, a longtime collaborator of Sorrentino, was announced as lead actor on 4 December 2024. In May 2025, Massimo Venturiello revealed his participation in the film. ### Filming Prior to principal photography, Sorrentino conducted location scouting throughout [Piedmont](/article/en/Piedmont). Principal photography began in March 2025 in [Turin](/article/en/Turin). Filming lasted approximately nine weeks, concluding by early May 2025. Filming locations in Turin included: * [Castello del Valentino](/article/en/Castello_del_Valentino) * [Moncalieri Castle](/article/en/Moncalieri_Castle) * Palazzo Chiablese * [Polytechnic University of Turin](/article/en/Polytechnic_University_of_Turin) * Accademia delle Scienze di Torino (Academy of Sciences, home to the [Egyptian Museum](/article/en/Egyptian_Museum_(Turin))) * Lorusso and Cutugno Prison (Vallette) * Bocciofila "Tesoriera" (in the Parella district) Additional filming took place at [Piazza di Spagna](/article/en/Piazza_di_Spagna) in [Rome](/article/en/Rome), the historic center of Rome between Via dei Condotti, the [Scala Theater](/article/en/La_Scala) in [Milan](/article/en/Milan), the countryside of the [Modena](/article/en/Modena) region, and [Mantua](/article/en/Mantua). ### Crew For cinematography and editing, Sorrentino relied on longtime collaborators [Daria D'Antonio](/article/en/Daria_D'Antonio) (cinematography) and [Cristiano Travaglioli](/article/en/Cristiano_Travaglioli) (editing). Costume design was by Carlo Poggioli. The film was produced by production companies The Apartment, Numero 10, and PiperFilm. The film has a runtime of 131 minutes and was shot in color. ## Release ### Distribution In February 2025, [MUBI](/article/en/MUBI), a streaming platform, acquired worldwide distribution rights excluding Italy. MUBI distributes in [North America](/article/en/North_America), [Latin America](/article/en/Latin_America), the [United Kingdom](/article/en/United_Kingdom), [Ireland](/article/en/Ireland), [Germany](/article/en/Germany), [Austria](/article/en/Austria), the [Benelux](/article/en/Benelux) countries, [Spain](/article/en/Spain), [Turkey](/article/en/Turkey), [India](/article/en/India), [Australia](/article/en/Australia), and [New Zealand](/article/en/New_Zealand), with their subsidiary The Match Factory handling sales in other territories. In Italy, PiperFilm distributes the film domestically. In [France](/article/en/France), the film is distributed by [Pathé Films](/article/en/Pathé_Films). ### Festival and theatrical releases During a Q&A session at [SXSW London](/article/en/SXSW) in June 2025, MUBI CEO Efe Cakarel hinted that *La grazia* would premiere at the 82nd Venice International Film Festival. This was confirmed in July 2025, with the film announced as the festival's opening film. The film premiered on 27 August 2025 at the [82nd Venice International Film Festival](/article/en/82nd_Venice_International_Film_Festival) in competition for the [Golden Lion](/article/en/Golden_Lion). It subsequently screened at the [New York Film Festival](/article/en/New_York_Film_Festival) and the [BFI London Film Festival](/article/en/BFI_London_Film_Festival). It received theatrical release in Italy on 15 January 2026, with preview screenings from 25 December 2025 to 1 January 2026 exclusively in morning slots. In France, the film was released on 28 January 2026. ## Reception ### Critical response On [Rotten Tomatoes](/article/en/Rotten_Tomatoes), 80% of 46 critics' reviews are positive, with the consensus reading: "Celebrating the virtues of fortitude and patience, La Grazia is an atypically restrained effort from writer-director Paolo Sorrentino that reunites him with the dependably majestic Toni Servillo." One source notes that 76 percent of reviews exceeded 20 English-language reviews received positive ratings. On [Metacritic](/article/en/Metacritic), which uses a weighted average, the film received a score of 69 out of 100 based on 12 critics, indicating "generally favorable" reviews. ### Box office The film grossed €3,689,433 in Italy. ## Accolades ### 82nd Venice International Film Festival (2025) * **[Volpi Cup for Best Actor](/article/en/Volpi_Cup)** – Toni Servillo * Brian Award * Pasinetti Award * In competition for the [Golden Lion](/article/en/Golden_Lion) This marked Sorrentino's second invitation to compete for the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival, following [2021](/article/en/2021_Venice_Film_Festival). The jury was headed by [Alexander Payne](/article/en/Alexander_Payne). ### European Film Awards (2026) * Nomination for Best Actor – Toni Servillo * Nomination for Best Screenplay – Paolo Sorrentino ## See also * [Euthanasia in Italy](/article/en/Euthanasia_in_Italy) * [Paolo Sorrentino](/article/en/Paolo_Sorrentino) – Filmography * [Toni Servillo](/article/en/Toni_Servillo) – Filmography * [82nd Venice International Film Festival](/article/en/82nd_Venice_International_Film_Festival) ## References ## External links * [La grazia at IMDb](https://www.imdb.com) * [La grazia at Rotten Tomatoes](https://www.rottentomatoes.com) * [La grazia at Metacritic](https://www.metacritic.com) * [La grazia at Box Office Mojo](https://www.boxofficemojo.com) * [La grazia in the Venice Festival Program](https://www.labiennale.org)
